qas.question: In which year did Poland declassify most of its Warsaw Pact-era archives?
What was the name of the Warsaw Pact's planned counteroffensive to a NATO first strike?

answers.text: Seven Days to the River Rhine

qas.question: How many nuclear weapons were eventually housed in Poland?
In which year was the counteroffensive strategy first conceived?
Who published classified documents in January 2006?
What originated as a 1989 field training exercise war game?

plausible_answers.text: Seven Days to the River Rhine

qas.question: What plan gave commanders many defensive-war strategies for fighting NATO?

context: In November <a0_0>2005<a0_0/>, the Polish government opened its Warsaw Treaty archives to the <b5_0>Institute of National Remembrance<b5_0/>, who published some 1,300 declassified documents in January 2006. Yet the <b6_0>Polish government<b6_0/> reserved publication of 100 documents, pending their military declassification. Eventually, 30 of the reserved 100 documents were published; <a1_0>70<a1_0/> remained secret, and unpublished. Among the documents published is the Warsaw Treaty's nuclear war plan, <a2_0>Seven Days to the River Rhine<a2_0/> – a short, swift counter-attack capturing Austria, Denmark, Germany and Netherlands east of River Rhine, using nuclear weapons, in self-defense, after a NATO first strike. The plan originated as a <a4_0>1979<a4_0/> field training exercise war game, and metamorphosed into official <b7_0>Warsaw Treaty battle doctrine<b7_0/>, until the late 1980s – which is why the People's Republic of Poland was a nuclear weapons base, first, to 178, then, to <a3_0>250<a3_0/> tactical-range rockets. Doctrinally, as a Soviet-style (offensive) battle plan, <b8_0>Seven Days to the River Rhine<b8_0/> gave commanders few defensive-war strategies for fighting NATO in Warsaw Treaty territory.[citation needed]
